channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: Goldman Leads in a Patchy Year for Foreign Banks in Japan
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. was among major global banks to post lower profit in Japan last year, pulling back from a bumper 2023.
item.dc:creator: Takashi Nakamichi

item.title: Stock Futures, Treasuries Drop After US Downgrade: Markets Wrap
item.description: US equity-index futures dropped and Treasuries yield curve steepened after Moody’s Ratings stripped the US government of its top credit rating, citing a ballooning budget deficit it said showed little sign of narrowing.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

media:content.media:description: An American flag is displayed outside the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Monday, July 2, 2018. U.S. stocks fell on lower than normal volume as investors waved off stronger than expected manufacturing numbers and focused on fears of increasing global trade tensions.

item.title: China’s Home Prices Drop at Faster Pace During Tariff War
item.description: China’s home prices fell at a faster pace in April, signaling the property market slump remains a headache for policymakers as they fend off trade tensions with the US.
item.dc:creator: Venus Feng, Emma Dong

item.title: Maybank Facilitates $545 Million Investments Into Economic Zone
item.description: Malaysia’s largest lender Malayan Banking Bhd. facilitated as much as 2.35 billion ringgit ($545 million) in client investments into the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone as part of efforts to promote the region.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

item.title: Taiwan Seeks LNG Cargoes After Shutting Last Nuclear Reactor
item.description: Taiwan is seeking liquefied natural gas shipments following the shutdown of its last nuclear reactor, a move that will increase the island’s reliance on the seaborne fuel.
item.dc:creator: Sing Yee Ong, Stephen Stapczynski

media:content.media:description: Storage tanks for LNG. Photographer: Annie Sakkab/Bloomberg

item.title: The UK Is Taxing an Oil Windfall That Doesn’t Exist
item.description: Let common sense prevail in the government about the North Sea.
item.dc:creator: Javier Blas

media:content.media:description: BARROW-IN-FURNESS, ENGLAND - MARCH 20: Prime Minister Keir Starmer speaks to the media after addressing Royal Navy Submariners of the HMS Agamemnon nuclear submarine and BAE systems apprentices outside of the BAE systems factory on March 20, 2025 in Barrow-in-Furness, United Kingdom. The UK's existing nuclear deterrent program, or continuous at sea deterrent (CASD), is comprised of four Trident missile Vanguard Class Submarines, which are set to be replaced with four new Dreadnought Class submarines. Recently, the UK has come under pressure to decrease its dependence on America for the manufacturing and maintenance of its nuclear program, as US President Donald Trump casts doubt on the future of a US commitment to the NATO alliance. (Photo by Oli Scarff - WPA Pool/Getty Images)

item.title: Mini ‘Sell America’ Trade Revived After Moody’s Downgrades US
item.description: Investors faced yet another bumpy start to the trading week with US assets coming under fresh pressure, although it’s mounting concern over American debt rather than tariffs generating the volatility this time.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova, Carmen Reinicke, Anya Andrianova

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. US stocks were on pace to snap a three-day winning streak Thursday, driven by declines in technology, energy and retailers as traders assessed a slew of mixed economic figures.

item.title: Oil Steadies After Early Drop With Ukraine, US Outlook in Focus
item.description: Oil steadied after an early drop, with talks to end the war in Ukraine and a lowering of the US credit rating in focus.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin

media:content.media:description: Exxon Mobil Corp. oil drilling rigs near Stanton, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 15, 2025. The Permian Basin, a sprawling shale patch that lies beneath Texas and New Mexico, is North America's most prolific shale patch.

item.title: Alibaba Shares Slide as AI Deal With Apple Faces US Scrutiny
item.description: Shares of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. slumped after a report that the Trump administration has raised concerns over Apple Inc.’s potential deal with the Chinese technology firm.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

item.title: Covid Test, Vaccine Maker Stocks Jump as Cases Surge in Asia
item.description: Shares of Covid test kit and drug makers in Asia rose following a surge of cases.
item.dc:creator: Sangmi Cha

item.title: Bloomberg: The Asia Trade 05/19/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Hong Kong and Singapore with Yvonne Man and Avril Hong, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China’s Factory Output Grows More Than Forecast Despite Tariffs
item.description: China’s industrial output expanded faster than expected in April, highlighting the resilience of the world’s second-largest economy and feeding optimism about growth following a quick de-escalation of trade tensions with the US. Goldman Sachs Chief China Economist Hui Shan and Credit Agricole Chief China Economist Xiaojia Zhi share their insights on the latest snapshot of China's economy. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China’s Fossil Fuels Production Retreats From Record Levels
item.description: Chinese fossil fuels output fell in April from the record levels hit in the prior month, although natural gas, crude oil and coal all delivered increases compared to the previous year as the government continues to prioritize security of supply despite weaker prices.
item.dc:creator: Jason Rogers

item.title: Baidu, Bilibili, Lenovo Report as US-China Trade Tensions Ease
item.description: Baidu Inc., Bilibili Inc. and Lenovo Group Ltd. are among the Chinese tech firms in focus for this week’s earnings, just as the easing US-China trade war brings back some optimism for the sector.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo, Justina T Lee, Harshita Swaminathan, Reina Sasaki

media:content.media:description: A screen demonstrates a Taichi learning software utilizing AI and motion capture technology during the Baidu Inc. Create AI Developer Conference in Wuhan, China, on Friday, April 25, 2025. Baidu unveiled upgrades to its flagship AI models and slashed their prices as it looks to take on rivals like Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. and DeepSeek in China's increasingly competitive artificial intelligence market.

item.title: Bulls Regain Appetite for Indian State-Owned Stocks
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty

item.title: Carry Trade Window Opens on Easing Trade Tensions, Barclays Says
item.description: Carry trades may make a near-term comeback as easing US-China tariff tensions reduce pressure on central banks to cut interest rates, according to Barclays Plc.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani

item.title: Top Hong Kong Builder Saw Weekend Sales Frenzy
item.description: Hong Kong’s biggest property developer Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd. sold another 376 flats on Sunday after receiving more than 34,000 bids, becoming one of the most sought after projects in months thanks to low interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Venus Feng

item.title: Singapore Bourse Risks More Delistings Despite New Proposals
item.description: Singapore’s move to simplify the initial public offering process, part of recent measures to boost its moribund equities market, is unlikely to reverse a yearslong trend of delistings crowding out new listings, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng, Justina T Lee

media:content.media:description: A person riding an escalator is reflected at the Singapore Exchange Ltd. (SGX) headquarters in Singapore, on Tuesday, Feb. 7, 2023. SGX is scheduled to release earnings results on Feb. 9.

item.title: Hedge Funds Reload Long Yen Trades Ahead of Kato-Bessent Meeting
item.description: Hedge funds and long-term investors are re-entering trades looking for the yen to rally ahead of potential currency talks this week between the US and Japan.
item.dc:creator: David Finnerty

item.title: Goldman Sachs Raises Topix Target on Improved Macro Outlook
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. strategists say Japan’s Topix stock gauge will benefit from a more benign macro outlook and improved sentiment for risk-taking after a cooling in US-China tariff tensions.
item.dc:creator: Aya Wagatsuma

item.title: Gold Gets Bounce From Moody’s US Downgrade After Big Weekly Drop
item.description: Gold bounced back after its biggest weekly decline in six months, with appetite for haven assets boosted by mounting concerns about the US economic outlook and budget deficit.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: Polish Ballot Set to Jolt Zloty as Pro-EU Front-Runner Pressured
item.description: A stronger-than-expected showing by opposition populists in the first round of Poland’s presidential election will test investor appetite for the country’s assets.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski, Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski, mayor of Warsaw, center, waves a Polish flag during an election night rally in Sandomierz, Poland, on Sunday, May 18, 2025. Trzaskowski, the centrist Warsaw mayor, and Karol Nawrocki, a pro-Donald Trump nationalist, came neck-and-neck in the first round of Poland's presidential election, according to an exit poll, in a blow to the pro-European government.

item.title: China-US Trade Truce Prompts Nations to Consider Tougher Tactics
item.description: China’s defiant stance in negotiating a tariff truce with the US has convinced some countries they need to take a tougher position in their own trade talks with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump during a Congressional resolution signing in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 9.

item.title: Options Traders Wary of Trump Treat China Rally With Caution
item.description: The de-escalation of the trade war has brought some relief to the market globally. Yet when it comes to Chinese equities, investors remain reluctant to bet on big gains moving forward.
item.dc:creator: David Marino, Sangmi Cha

item.title: Indonesia Rupiah to Extend Rally on Fiscal Hopes, Weak Dollar
item.description: Indonesia’s rupiah is set to extend gains in the second half of the year on hopes over prudent fiscal management and a bearish outlook for the US currency, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani

item.title: UK Home Asking Prices Rise to Record High as Demand Rebounds
item.description: Asking prices for UK homes rose to a new record high in May and demand picked up in a sign of the property market’s resilience after the end of a tax cut for buyers.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: Chinese Trader Who Made $1.5 Billion on Gold Builds a Giant Bet on Copper
item.description: Plastics billionaire Bian Ximing is all in on the red metal.
item.dc:creator: Alfred Cang

item.title: Five Key Charts to Watch in Global Commodity Markets This Week
item.description: The scrap copper industry in the US is hustling to move piled up supplies over to China now that the two superpowers have put their trade dispute on a temporary pause. South Korea’s homegrown atomic technology has the world’s attention. And, US Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s desire for diet changes has the potential to impact the global food supply chain.
item.dc:creator: Jack Wittels, Alex Longley, Yvonne Yue Li, Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: Customers refuel at a Love's gas station in Dallas, Texas, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Oil has trended lower since late January due to escalating trade frictions and plans by OPEC+ to keep boosting idled supply, but prices have moved away from their lows in the last couple of days.

item.title: Hope Springs in German C-Suites as Gloom Starts to Lift
item.description: A vibe shift is underway in Europe’s largest economy. Plus, the CFO of India’s Tata Communications discusses growth plans, geopolitics and more.
item.dc:creator: Nina Trentmann

media:content.media:description: German CFOs are cautiously optimistic that the country’s new government can get the economy back on track. Photo credit: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Midpoint of Trump Tariff Hiatus to Reveal Increasingly Unsettled World
item.description: Reports in the coming week may give the fullest reading to date of how major economies are faring with trade disruptions, halfway through President Donald Trump’s 90-day hiatus on so-called reciprocal tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Idle gantry cranes at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, May 12, 2025. Recent data showed a slump in trade across the Pacific Ocean, fueling worries that Trump's broad tariff agenda could hit American consumers with higher prices and fewer choices and spur a global downturn.
